verses.verse: The words<WH1697> of Agur<WH94> the son<WH1121> of Jakeh<WH3348>, even the prophecy<WH4853>: the man<WH1397> spake<WH5002> unto Ithiel<WH384>, even unto Ithiel<WH384> and Ucal<WH401>,
Surely I am more brutish<WH1198> than any man<WH376>, and have not the understanding<WH998> of a man<WH120>.
I neither learned<WH3925> wisdom<WH2451>, nor have<WH3045> the knowledge<WH1847> of the holy<WH6918>. have: Heb. know

Who hath ascended up<WH5927> into heaven<WH8064>, or descended<WH3381>? who hath gathered<WH622> the wind<WH7307> in his fists<WH2651>? who hath bound<WH6887> the waters<WH4325> in a garment<WH8071>? who hath established<WH6965> all the ends<WH657> of the earth<WH776>? what is his name<WH8034>, and what is his son's<WH1121> name<WH8034>, if thou canst tell<WH3045>?
Every word<WH565> of God<WH433> is pure<WH6884>: he is a shield<WH4043> unto them that put their trust<WH2620> in him. pure: Heb. purified
Add<WH3254> thou not unto his words<WH1697>, lest he reprove<WH3198> thee, and thou be found a liar<WH3576>.
Two<WH8147> things have I required<WH7592> of thee; deny<WH4513> me them not before I die<WH4191>: deny: Heb. withhold not from me

Remove far<WH7368> from me vanity<WH7723> and lies<WH1697> <WH3577>: give<WH5414> me neither poverty<WH7389> nor riches<WH6239>; feed<WH2963> me with food<WH3899> convenient<WH2706> for me: convenient: Heb. of my allowance

Lest I be full<WH7646>, and deny<WH3584> thee, and say<WH559>, Who is the LORD<WH3068>? or lest I be poor<WH3423>, and steal<WH1589>, and take<WH8610> the name<WH8034> of my God<WH430> in vain. deny: Heb. belie thee
Accuse<WH3960> not a servant<WH5650> unto his master<WH113>, lest he curse<WH7043> thee, and thou be found guilty<WH816>. Accuse: Heb. Hurt not with thy tongue
There is a generation<WH1755> that curseth<WH7043> their father<WH1>, and doth not bless<WH1288> their mother<WH517>.
There is a generation<WH1755> that are pure<WH2889> in their own eyes<WH5869>, and yet is not washed<WH7364> from their filthiness<WH6675>.
There is a generation<WH1755>, O how lofty<WH7311> are their eyes<WH5869>! and their eyelids<WH6079> are lifted up<WH5375>.

There is a generation<WH1755>, whose teeth<WH8127> are as swords<WH2719>, and their jaw teeth<WH4973> as knives<WH3979>, to devour<WH398> the poor<WH6041> from off the earth<WH776>, and the needy<WH34> from among men<WH120>.

The horseleach<WH5936> hath two<WH8147> daughters<WH1323>, crying, Give<WH3051>, give<WH3051>. There are three<WH7969> things that are never satisfied<WH7646>, yea, four<WH702> things say<WH559> not, It is enough<WH1952>: It is: Heb. Wealth
The grave<WH7585>; and the barren<WH6115> womb<WH7356>; the earth<WH776> that is not filled<WH7646> with water<WH4325>; and the fire<WH784> that saith<WH559> not, It is enough<WH1952>.

The eye<WH5869> that mocketh<WH3932> at his father<WH1>, and despiseth<WH936> to obey<WH3349> his mother<WH517>, the ravens<WH6158> of the valley<WH5158> shall pick it out<WH5365>, and the young<WH1121> eagles<WH5404> shall eat<WH398> it. the valley: or, the brook
There be three<WH7969> things which are too wonderful<WH6381> for me, yea, four<WH702> which I know<WH3045> not:

The way<WH1870> of an eagle<WH5404> in the air<WH8064>; the way<WH1870> of a serpent<WH5175> upon a rock<WH6697>; the way<WH1870> of a ship<WH591> in the midst<WH3820> of the sea<WH3220>; and the way<WH1870> of a man<WH1397> with a maid<WH5959>. midst: Heb. heart
Such is the way<WH1870> of an adulterous<WH5003> woman<WH802>; she eateth<WH398>, and wipeth<WH4229> her mouth<WH6310>, and saith<WH559>, I have done<WH6466> no wickedness<WH205>.
For three<WH7969> things the earth<WH776> is disquieted<WH7264>, and for four<WH702> which it cannot<WH3201> bear<WH5375>:
For a servant<WH5650> when he reigneth<WH4427>; and a fool<WH5036> when he is filled<WH7646> with meat<WH3899>;
For an odious<WH8130> woman when she is married<WH1166>; and an handmaid<WH8198> that is heir<WH3423> to her mistress<WH1404>.
There be four<WH702> things which are little<WH6996> upon the earth<WH776>, but they are exceeding<WH2449> wise<WH2450>: exceeding: Heb. wise, made wise
The ants<WH5244> are a people<WH5971> not strong<WH5794>, yet they prepare<WH3559> their meat<WH3899> in the summer<WH7019>;
The conies<WH8227> are but a feeble<WH6099> folk<WH5971>, yet make<WH7760> they their houses<WH1004> in the rocks<WH5553>;
The locusts<WH697> have no king<WH4428>, yet go they forth<WH3318> all of them by bands<WH2686>; by: Heb. gathered together
The spider<WH8079> taketh hold<WH8610> with her hands<WH3027>, and is in kings'<WH4428> palaces<WH1964>.
There be three<WH7969> things which go<WH6806> well<WH3190>, yea, four<WH702> are comely<WH2895> in going<WH3212>:
A lion<WH3918> which is strongest<WH1368> among beasts<WH929>, and turneth not away<WH7725> for<WH6440> any;
A greyhound<WH4975> <WH2223>; an he goat<WH8495> also<WH176>; and a king<WH4428>, against whom there is no rising up<WH510>. greyhound: or, horse: Heb. girt in the loins
If thou hast done foolishly<WH5034> in lifting up<WH5375> thyself, or if thou hast thought evil<WH2161>, lay thine hand<WH3027> upon thy mouth<WH6310>.

Surely the churning<WH4330> of milk<WH2461> bringeth forth<WH3318> butter<WH2529>, and the wringing<WH4330> of the nose<WH639> bringeth forth<WH3318> blood<WH1818>: so the forcing<WH4330> of wrath<WH639> bringeth forth<WH3318> strife<WH7379>.
